Award.AwardTitle: Revealing Exoplanet Atmospheres With Ground-Based Transmission Spectroscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports work to measure the chemical composition of ten transiting extrasolar planets (planets that appear to pass in front of their host star when observed from the Earth). The PI and his team will use the Gemini Observatory North and South telescopes to obtain optical spectra of the planets using the technique called transmission spectroscopy, which analyzes starlight after it passes through the transiting planet's atmosphere. To accomplish this, they will develop and use improved observational techniques of ground-based spectroscopy, make comparative studies of the planets, and test models of planetary systems formation and evolution. These observations will be incorporated into undergraduate and graduate laboratory classes taught by the PI. The PI will train and mentor a graduate student in technical and scientific skills. The data and analysis pipeline and atmospheric archive of the planets will be made publicly available through a web archive.

This program consists of observing a subset of close-in gas giant exoplanets during transit. The observations are obtained using guaranteed time on the GMOS (Gemini Multi-Object-Spectrograph) instruments with low-resolution dispersive elements. The atmospheric survey will be carried out at optical (400 - 1000 nm) wavelengths and will simultaneously observe calibration and target objects. The data will be used to measure the abundances of water, methane, haze particles, and, potentially, a speculated optical absorber from transmission spectra.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have been awarded a NSF grant in order to address the question of exoplanet composition and diversity from a statistical stand point. The goal of our project was to develop a comparative exoplanetology survey program using the existing main classes of known transiting giant planets. Our strategy was to use the technique of multi-object spectroscopic (MOS) observations to obtain transmission spectra of their atmospheres. We secured a wealth of multi-wavelength transmission spectroscopic measurements to study the composition of nine gas giant exoplanet atmospheres. This survey was carried out at optical (400 - 1000 nm) wavelength with the Gemini/GMOS facility. The abundances of water, methane, haze particles, and, potentially, a speculated optical absorber is determined from transmission spectra by comparing to atmospheric models. Overall, this project has opened a new window on the field of comparative exoplanetology.

 We found that clouds are ubiquitous despite the broad range of planet temperatures and masses explored in our survey and that about 10%, or less,  of exoplanets have clear atmospheres, free of aerosols, clouds, haze or any form of condensation. This was unknown before and has major impacts on the future of exoplanet atmospheric characterization.  Only one planet in our sample is found to be cloud-free, from which we can measure the metallicity as traced by the alkali metals. There are only two planets so far for which such measurements can be made. Amongst the first time, spectra of exoplanet using the MOS technique show atmospheric signatures of alkali metals. Indeed, we identified the signature of the sodium and potassium present in the atmospheres of exoplanets and measure abundances. In addition, this project provided the first refractory over volatile measurement for an exoplanet (Na/O), together with a measure of the absolute metallicity. This is a crucial measurement for constraining planet formation location as this was planned in the initial proposal. 

 Overall, We established that the precision achieved by GMOS is comparable to HST/STIS, but that GMOS’d data has systematic errors that make it challenging to study exoplanet atmospheres.  We provided great details about the method for the reduction and analysis pipeline as well as recipes for producing transmission spectra in a first paper that is comprehensive, and written in such a way that anyone can reproduce our findings. This paper is quickly becoming a reference for the field of Multi-Object Spectroscopy applied to exoplanets. Importantly, we also highlighted important issues that were not properly treated in previous studies, which alter significantly previous conclusion. Thus, our work has an impact for future studies, but also in providing context to previous studies.
